column1: One night the stranger awoke—he slept with the doors of the balcony open—the curtain before it was raised by the wind
column2: and he thought that a strange lustre came from the opposite neighbor's house; all the flowers shone like flames
column4: and in the midst of the flowers stood a slender
column5: graceful maiden—it was as if she also shone; the light really hurt his eyes. He now opened them quite wide—yes
column6: he was quite awake; with one spring he was on the floor; he crept gently behind the curtain
column7: but the maiden was gone; the flowers shone no longer
column9: fresh and blooming as ever; the door was ajar
column12: the music sounded so soft and delightful
column13: one could really melt away in sweet thoughts from it. Yet it was like a piece of enchantment. And who lived there? Where was the actual entrance? The whole of the ground-floor was a row of shops
column14: and there people could not always be running through.
